citations.desc: Attending veterinarian and adequate veterinary care (dealers and exhibitors).
citations.narrative:
One male rabbit “Dr. Doom” was prescribed Metacam by the veterinarian. The instructions were to give the medication
two times per day from 5/9/23 to 5/16/23; however, the facility ran out of medication on 5/13/23. The treatment was
discontinued and the veterinarian was not contacted for additional medication or instructions.
Not following the attending veterinarian’s instructions for medications can lead to inadequate treatment of issues and
worsened outcomes for the animals. The facility must give medications as directed by the attending veterinarian. The
facility must use appropriate methods to prevent, control, diagnose, and treat diseases and injuries.
To be corrected by 6/10/2023.

citations.desc: Attending veterinarian and adequate veterinary care (dealers and exhibitors).
citations.narrative:
There are multiple instances where animal health concerns were not communicated to the attending veterinarian in a
timely manner.
- One adult female cat “Emily” was taken to the veterinarian on 2/20/23 for vomiting after eating, weight loss, and
coughing. The cat was held at the clinic and returned to the facility on 2/23/23. A few days later, a maintenance worker
noticed that the cat seemed very ill and was struggling to breathe. This individual notified the animal caretaker and others
that the cat was not doing well; however, the cat was not euthanized until 2/28/23. On the day she was euthanized, her
medical record at the clinic stated that she continued to cough and vomit after being taken back to the ranch. The page for
February in the daily observation notebook has been torn out and there is no other record of communication regarding the
cat’s condition between 2/23/23 and 2/28/23.
- One adult goat “Acorn” was seen limping on 5/9/23 but the veterinarian was not contacted until 5/12/23 about the
condition. There is no information regarding lameness in the Program of Veterinary Care.
- Two adult beagles (“Ryder” and “Braveheart”) got into a fight that resulted in injuries to one of the dogs. Staff said that
part of Ryder’s ear had been torn off, he was limping, and there were also two punctures or scratches on his front leg. The
staff cleaned the wounds and administered 50mg of Rimadyl. This was done without contacting the veterinarian and there
are no instructions in the Program of Veterinary Care. When the director spoke with the veterinarian a few weeks after the
fight, the veterinarian stated that he would have wanted to clean the wounds himself and place the animal on antibiotics.
Failure to observe medical problems and/or communicate those problems to a veterinarian can result in prolonged
medical conditions and ongoing pain. A facility representative must observe all animals daily and then ensure a
mechanism of direct and frequent communication with a veterinarian so that timely and accurate information on problems
of health, behavior, and well-being are conveyed.
To be corrected by 6/10/2023.

The facility has two recorded incidents where the male German Shepherd “Nayati” injured a visitor. On 5/15/22, a visitor
was interacting with the dog when he lunged and bit her nose, requiring five stitches. On 4/11/23, a teenage volunteer
accompanied a staff member into the dog yard. Nayati reacted to their presence and pushed through a gate to reach
them. The volunteer was bitten on the wrist and received medical care for this injury. The facility stated that there is no
formal training for volunteers. The facility also stated that they may have been lax due to familiarity in both incidents. On
4/12/23, Nayati was euthanized due to aggression.
Putting a known reactive dog with a history of aggression in a situation where it could have close contact with untrained
volunteers or visitors can lead to injury of the dog and the public. Exposing a sensitive dog to unfamiliar individuals can
result in increased anxiety in the dog. Handling of all animals shall be done as expeditiously and carefully as possible in a
manner that does not cause trauma, overheating, excessive cooling, behavioral stress, physical harm, or unnecessary
discomfort.
To be corrected by 6/10/2023.

At the cat building, there is a spot on the outdoor fence where the wires have broken and created a hole that is
approximately ten inches long. Additional broken wires allow this space to be stretched open vertically to approximately
two inches.
In the Dog 1 building, there is an area of damaged drywall next to an electrical outlet. There are signs of claw marks from
dogs digging at the spot and it is beginning to open a hole behind the outlet wall plate.
Broken fencing wires can allow animals to escape, allow other animals to enter, or cause injury. Damaged drywall near an
outlet can expose electrical wires and cause injury. Housing facilities for dogs and cats must be designed and constructed
so that they are structurally sound. They must be kept in good repair, and they must protect the animals from injury,
contain the animals securely, and restrict other animals from entering.
To be corrected 6/14/2023.
This inspection and exit interview were conducted with facility representatives.
n

narrative:
2.40(b)(2) 
   
Attending veterinarian and adequate veterinary care (dealers and exhibitors). 
One male rabbit “Dr. Doom” was prescribed Metacam by the veterinarian. The instructions were to give the medication 
two times per day from 5/9/23 to 5/16/23; however, the facility ran out of medication on 5/13/23. The treatment was 
discontinued and the veterinarian was not contacted for additional medication or instructions.  
 
Not following the attending veterinarian’s instructions for medications can lead to inadequate treatment of issues and 
worsened outcomes for the animals. The facility must give medications as directed by the attending veterinarian. The 
facility must use appropriate methods to prevent, control, diagnose, and treat diseases and injuries. 
 
To be corrected by 6/10/2023. 
2.40(b)(3)  Critical
   
Attending veterinarian and adequate veterinary care (dealers and exhibitors). 
There are multiple instances where animal health concerns were not communicated to the attending veterinarian in a 
timely manner.  
 
- One adult female cat “Emily” was taken to the veterinarian on 2/20/23 for vomiting after eating, weight loss, and 
coughing. The cat was held at the clinic and returned to the facility on 2/23/23. A few days later, a maintenance worker

that the cat was not doing well; however, the cat was not euthanized until 2/28/23. On the day she was euthanized, her

February in the daily observation notebook has been torn out and there is no other record of communication regarding the 
cat’s condition between 2/23/23 and 2/28/23.  
 
- One adult goat “Acorn” was seen limping on 5/9/23 but the veterinarian was not contacted until 5/12/23 about the 
condition. There is no information regarding lameness in the Program of Veterinary Care.  
 
- Two adult beagles (“Ryder” and “Braveheart”) got into a fight that resulted in injuries to one of the dogs. Staff said that 
part of Ryder’s ear had been torn off, he was limping, and there were also two punctures or scratches on his front leg. The

staff cleaned the wounds and administered 50mg of Rimadyl. This was done without contacting the veterinarian and there 
are no instructions in the Program of Veterinary Care. When the director spoke with the veterinarian a few weeks after the 
fight, the veterinarian stated that he would have wanted to clean the wounds himself and place the animal on antibiotics. 
 
Failure to observe medical problems and/or communicate those problems to a veterinarian can result in prolonged 
medical conditions and ongoing pain. A facility representative must observe all animals daily and then ensure a 
mechanism of direct and frequent communication with a veterinarian so that timely and accurate information on problems 
of health, behavior, and well-being are conveyed. 
 
To be corrected by 6/10/2023. 
2.131(b)(1)  Critical
   
Handling of animals. 
The facility has two recorded incidents where the male German Shepherd “Nayati” injured a visitor. On 5/15/22, a visitor 
was interacting with the dog when he lunged and bit her nose, requiring five stitches. On 4/11/23, a teenage volunteer 
accompanied a staff member into the dog yard. Nayati reacted to their presence and pushed through a gate to reach 
them. The volunteer was bitten on the wrist and received medical care for this injury. The facility stated that there is no 
formal training for volunteers. The facility also stated that they may have been lax due to familiarity in both incidents. On 
4/12/23, Nayati was euthanized due to aggression.  
 
Putting a known reactive dog with a history of aggression in a situation where it could have close contact with untrained 
volunteers or visitors can lead to injury of the dog and the public. Exposing a sensitive dog to unfamiliar individuals can 
result in increased anxiety in the dog. Handling of all animals shall be done as expeditiously and carefully as possible in a 
manner that does not cause trauma, overheating, excessive cooling, behavioral stress, physical harm, or unnecessary 
discomfort. 
 
To be corrected by 6/10/2023. 
3.1(a) 
   
Housing facilities, general. 
At the cat building, there is a spot on the outdoor fence where the wires have broken and created a hole that is 
approximately ten inches long. Additional broken wires allow this space to be stretched open vertically to approximately 
two inches. 
 
In the Dog 1 building, there is an area of damaged drywall next to an electrical outlet. There are signs of claw marks from 
dogs digging at the spot and it is beginning to open a hole behind the outlet wall plate.  
 
Broken fencing wires can allow animals to escape, allow other animals to enter, or cause injury. Damaged drywall near an 
outlet can expose electrical wires and cause injury. Housing facilities for dogs and cats must be designed and constructed 
so that they are structurally sound. They must be kept in good repair, and they must protect the animals from injury, 
contain the animals securely, and restrict other animals from entering.

To be corrected 6/14/2023. 
 
This inspection and exit interview were conducted with facility representatives.

species.common: DOMESTIC PIG / POTBELLY PIG / MICRO PIG
